All these remarks (from Craig, J.B Rainsberger, Paul) are fine to me 
but the bottom line remains...

It seems we all agreed that :
  _ Equality ***must*** be "commutative"
    (i.e. A.equals (B) must return the same result as B.equals (A))
  _ Testing the equals implementation should not be made 
    via the usage of the assertEquals (msg, expected, actual)
    but tru' the usage of some add-ons or ...
  
However, 
should one be willing to test the equality of two objects, the 
assertion should fail if the commutativity is not successfully met.

I think this mail could close the remark ...

;-)

Thomas,


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Demyanovich, Craig - Apogent" 
<cdemyanovich@a...> wrote:
> Thomas,
> 
> The contract for the equals method on class Object 
> states that the "method implements an equivalence 
> relation:  ...It is symmetric: for any reference
> values x and y, x.equals(y) should return true 
> if and only if y.equals(x) returns true...."  
> The JUnit code is written according to the documented
> contract of the equals method.  Therefore, the burden 
> lies on you to implement an equals method that 
> honors the contract.
> 
> Joshua Bloch, in his book, _Effective Java_, 
> has explained very well how to write a good 
> implementation of the equals method.  Furthermore, 
> it is not very difficult to write a good JUnit 
> TestCase to ensure that your equals
> implementation honors the contract.  
> I have written my own TestCase for this
> purpose, and the Junit-addons project 
> (http://junit-addons.sourceforge.net/)
> has a TestCase named EqualsHashCodeTestCase 
> that you can extend.
> 
> Craig
